feed.title: Re: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin

entry.title: Re: Against Allowing Quantum Recovery of Bitcoin
entry.summary:
The discussion centers around the security implications of spending timelocked coins that have not yet exposed their public keys, highlighting a nuanced edge case in cryptocurrency protocols. It is posited that for such transactions to be considered safe from quantum computing attacks, which could theoretically reverse engineer a key during the short time a transaction remains unconfirmed (in the mempool), quantum computers would need to achieve an extraordinary level of power. This scenario underscores the broader issue of how long-term timelocks, while serving as a tool for securing funds, introduce potential vulnerabilities and necessitate future fund migrations due to protocol weaknesses that might emerge over time.
Moreover, the conversation touches upon the personal apprehension associated with setting timelocks for durations extending beyond a year or two. This concern is rooted in the fear of locking oneself out from participating in critical decisions, especially in scenarios involving controversial chain forks where the ability to "vote with your feet" by moving funds is crucial. Such situations exemplify the trade-offs between securing assets and retaining flexibility to respond to unforeseen developments within the blockchain ecosystem. This discourse was part of an exchange on the Bitcoin Development Mailing List, reflecting the ongoing dialogue among developers about the evolving challenges in cryptocurrency security and governance.
